title: The Biggie Dugout for Dynavap XL
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I finally came around and made the XL version available, happy printing!

This is currently made to hold the Stinger Quad Torch Lighter by Vertigo which is available over at Dynavap's website: https://www.dynavap.com/dynashop/accessories/quad-torch-lighter

The lighter's dimensions from the site show: 8.2cm x 3.5cm x 1.9cm

To fit, I measured with some calipers and made the lighter hole this size:

X,Y,Z (X)40mm x (Y)20mm x (Z)88mm

***Important, if you want your Dynavap to center in the magnet like the OG Dynastash, you will need to purchase a DIAMETRICALLY aligned magnet for the middle. If you do not specifically look for this you might end up with a magnet that is AXIALLY aligned by mistake and the Dynavap will not stick in the middle of your disc magnet. Trust me, I know this, I made this mistake.

***You can also just order the magnet provided by Dynavap in their website, but as I designed this with a thicker magnet disc, the one from Dynavap will look pushed in, I might design another case so that it looks almost flush and works with the magnet from Dynavap.

Disc Magnets needed:

2x Neodymium Magnets 1/4 x 1/16 (6mm x 1.5mm)
https://www.ebay.com/itm/50-Strong-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-Disc-Magnets-1-4-x-1-16-inch-New/261420345696?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

1x Diametric Neodymium Magnet 1/2 x 1/8 (13mm x 3mm)
https://www.ebay.com/itm/20-Neodymium-Magnets-1-2-x-1-8-inch-Disc-DIAMETRIC-N48/400076765754?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 or 0.3

Infill:

15% to 30%

Notes:

Since I made this with the intention of printing in PLA/Wood Filament. The Lid may be a loose fit when printing in other materials such as just PLA.

Z-axis Slider module for ZONESTAR P802M P802N and P802Q

This will allow you to turn a ground bloom flower into a rocket. To transform the ground bloom flower, remove the fuse(hang on to it, we will need it later) and unwrap the cardboard until you get to the glued seam at the thinnest point. From here, cove the fuse hole with 8 layers of aluminium foil and add tape to secure it. then drill a hole about 2 mm or 1/16 in (smallest hole possible) in the bottom clay of the firework until you reach the black powder. Put the fuse we saved earlier in this hole and tape it to secure it in place. then put the fuse through to hole in the print and push the firework into the hole on the print. From here, set it down and light the fuse(OUTDOORS!!!!!)

BE CAREFUL AND HAVE FUN!!!

DISCLAIMER: I AM NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY DAMAGES OR INJURIES CAUSED BY THE FIREWORK OR THE PRINT.

This lamp (a mix of laser cutting and 3D printed parts) started as an idea one day when playing with a scad script to create slot patterns in 1/8" wood with my laser cutter. I liked how the slotted wood allowed slits of light to shine thru, creating pretty shadows.

This lamp has 2 versions. The open-top version (pictured) and the closed-top version.

The finished lamps were coated with XTC-3D and sanded smooth. Then primed, painted with a metallic paint, and finished with a few glossy clear coats.

3D Printed
  • 1x - Bottom.stl
  • 1x - Top.stl [or Top_(Open).stl -- if creating open top version)
  • 1x - Top_Ring.stl (Only if printing open top version)
  • 3x - Pillar.stl
  • 3X - Rubber foot.stl
  • 6X (2 per shade minimum) - Wood_Form.stl -- See Instructions for details on this piece

All parts printed in PLA, expect "Rubber Feet" which I printed in NinjaFlex

Laser Cut
  • 1/8" (3.2mm) plywood (to create 3x lamp shades)
    • file: _Slotted_LampShade.dxf
  • .003 Diffusion Sheet (only for open-top version)
    • file: _LightDiffuser.dxf
Other Parts
  • 6x - M3x30mm flat-head screws
  • 3x - M3x8mm socket-head screws
  • 3x - M3 nuts
  • 2x - M4x30mm button-head screws
  • 2x - M4 nuts
  • Lamp Cord w/Dimmer
  • Lamp Socket
  • Kichler 40W Equivalent Dimmable Amber T9 Vintage LED Lamp - In the US, you can get these easily at Lowes.
  • .003 Diffuser Sheet - Only needed for open-top version.
  • Mineral Oil -- Butcher Block oil
  • Super Glue

Prepare the slotted lamp shades

The shades need to be steamed and bent to a slight curve. You will use the Word Form.stl printed tools to hold the pieces in place after steaming the wood.

  1. You need steam. I used a steam iron, cranked up to create lots of steam.
  2. Sandwich a single lamp shade in paper towels, lay flat, and then apply steam with the iron.
  3. Continue to do this, moving the iron over the wood to saturate the wood in steam
  4. After about 30-45 seconds, slow curve the wood (from the center outward)
  5. Use the Wood Form tool to hold the shade in place.
  6. Do this 2 more times for the other 2 shades.
  7. Leave overnight and let the humidity reduce in the wood. Do not remove the Wood Form tools
  8. Apply several generous coats of mineral oil to both sides of the shades. This will keep the wood from cracking/breaking, plus it gives great depth to the wood.
  9. I let these sit and soak up all the oil for a couple days with the Wood Form tools left on.
Preparing and Wiring Up the Base
  1. Push in 3x M3 nuts in the base. These are used to secure the rubber feet later.
  2. Pull the lamp cord thru the bottom round hole. Create a knot in the wire to keep the cord from being pulled back out.
  3. Put the lamp socket on the bottom base, aligning the mount holes in the socket with the base. With the lamp wire out of the way, insert the the 2 M4x30mm screws from the bottom of the base and thru the lamp socket. Use 2 M4 nuts to secure the socket to the base.
  4. Attach the wires to the socket and tighten down
  5. Screw in the light bulb and test your work.
Prepare the Open Top

Only required if building the open-top version

  1. Run a small bead of super glue around the inner rim of the top piece. Keep the glue to the outermost area so the glue doesn't become visible around the opening.
  2. Lay down the diffuser in its opening. Press down to make sure the glue spreads, but keep it away from the opening. Let this dry/set.
  3. Once the diffuser is set, apply the Top Ring piece over the diffused piece and apply more glue to secure the Ring to the Top piece. This is to act as a reinforcement so the diffuser piece isn't easily detached.
Attaching the Lamp Shades and Pillars to Lamp Top
  1. Before gluing anything, dry-fit all 3 shades and pillars to make sure they all fit in place. You will want to make sure all shades fit correctly in their curved slots on the TOP of the lamp.
    • You will notice that the top and the bottom of the Pillar pieces have 3mm holes. These are used for alignment and attaching the lamp. For the top of my lamps, I used 3mm printer filament for alignment. It's not required, but helps.
  2. Once everything aligns and fits properly, disassemble your pieces and one-at-a-time, you will glue the shades and pillars to the top of the lamp.
  3. First add a deep bead of glue inside one of the slots where the lampshade will fit.
  4. Push the curved lampshade into the glue-filled slot.
  5. Add glue to the top-side of a pillar and attached to 1 side of the shade. We only need to glue the top (not the sides) of the pillars.
  6. Repeat this process until you have all 3 shades and pillars attached to the top of the lamp.
  7. Leave the lamp upside down (e.g. the lamp top should be resting on the table). This is to keep the glue from running down the lamp shades. We want the glue to stay in the slots and harden. Leave it overnight to fully cure.
Attaching the top and the bottom
  1. Carefully align the assembled top piece with the bottom piece. The shades should drop into the slots on the bottom based and no gap should exist between the base and the pillars.
  2. The bottom of the lamp uses 6x M3x30 screws to attach the bottom to the pillars. Tighten all 6 evenly.
  3. Using the 3x M3x8mm screws, attach the rubber feet to the base.

Enjoy!

title: ANET A8 Z Endstop fine adjustment

description.text:
I did change two things:

  • The Leg has a 2.95 mm hole for 3mm screws which gives more stability, no more drilling or heating needed anymore.
  • The Foot is completely redesigned also for 3mm screw and has a big flat bottom and is easy to screw on to the screw and is used for calibration as a turning knob ;-)

Assembly instructions:

  • Mount the switch holder to the frame, add the switch
  • put a M3x35 or similar through the legs hole
  • add the foot to the screw, tighten it a little bit, not too much or you'll deform the bottom surface. You can glue the screw into the foot to give it a better hold.

Calibration:
just turn the screw using the six sided foot, enjoy!

Note:
A good calibrated printer is essential for the screws to fit the holes tightly!

If it doesn't fit, just scale the model up 1-3% ;-)

To set up your z axis, just remember: one complete turn of the M3 screw is 0.5 mm

remixed_from.author: dutchmogul
remixed_from.title: Sculptris OBJ Bits: Fantasy Pants and Skirts

title: Robin Spellhood, Magical Fantasy Woman
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Make sure before printing, that you scale it to the height you want. Ie, 15mm, 25mm, 28mm, etc.

A fantasy magical woman character with a wand and a magic orb, created in Sculptris with help from some of user DutchMogul's Sculptris files, and then further customised with sculpting and Blender.

This is my first sculpted 3D fantasy character, and is the main character of a solo, coop, or competitive, free-to-print and play, stealth-fantasy 3D board game that I am designing. The character is Princess Robin, who in exile is known as Robin Spellhood by the people. In her right hand is the Wand of Shadows that (if she can master its powers) grants her sneaky magical abilities, like being able to snuff out candle flames from across the room, while in her left hand is the Orb of True Sight which allows her to see a birds-eye view of the current board game level, seeing the movements of all the NPCs in the area so she can plan her movements and remain undetected.

If other people like the model, they are welcome to print it out or modify it for themselves, for their own fantasy miniatures gaming. I plan to release all the files for the Core Set of my board game for free, and if anyone wants to play it, they'll be able to download the appropriate files and assemble a copy of the game.

If you want to read any progress, I'm blogging about it on my fantasy miniatures blog:

https://paulslotrminis.blogspot.com.au/
I painted it using Citadel Games Workshop paints and washes.

It is based on user DutchMogul's free Sculptris files - a body to build from, and some clothing parts to decorate, then I did a bunch of personal scultping alterations to create the final STL product's appearance. Finally, I shrunk a magic staff from DutchMogul's OBJ weapons pack so it was only half as long but still as thick, to create the wand, and added a sphere in Blender for the Orb of True Vision.

I printed it off so that the round base is 15mm wide, and the character (including the base) was about 24.8mm tall I think.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100% (lots of shells)

Notes:

To print a lithophane I've heard you're supposed to print on it's edge for the best fidelity because the X-Y steppers have much finer resolution than the Z-axis (layer height).

Since it's supposed to be obstructing the light to get the shades of gray it's important to make sure it is completely filled. Simplify 3D is great for that because I can use it's variable width gap fill.

I printed with a skirt a few layers high to help it stick to the bed. 0.2mm offset from the lithophane itself.

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

Simple steps

Simply upload a photo to http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ and download the stl.

3D Builder wanted to "repair" the STL, so I let it to that.

A little more detail

A lithophane uses the thickness of the object to make it light & dark when a light is shined through it. Where the lithophane is thin it will be lighter, where it's thick it'll be darker.

I started with the photo of the cat's head in front of the house. It was a recent photo that I'd taken that I was pretty happy with.

Prepare the photo, upload it to http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ tweak some settings, and download the STL.

Prepare a photo
I used CorelDraw (& I confess, Windows Live Photo Gallery)

  • I removed the house using the magic wand tool to select the cat &/or house and copy to another layer or delete them.
  • My first pass (the color photo with no background) didn't have enough contrast in the STL for his orange stripes, so I adjusted the contrast and brightness.
  • Black & White shows the photo I uploaded. Converting it to black and white is easier to visualize the output.

Convert to STL

  • Go to http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/
  • Upload the photo on the "images" tab on top.
  • Switch to "Outer Curve" on the "model" tab on top. (hit refresh)
    Note that by default the tool makes the dark parts thinner. To shine a light through it we want the dark parts thicker.
  • On the "settings" tab change from Negative to Positive (we uploaded a positive).
  • Back on the "model" tab hit refresh.
  • Hit the download button

I had to "repair" the downloaded STL using 3D Builder. Not sure why.

Note that the settings tab has several other options as well. You can mirror the image, add a border and more.

I used the default "model settings" with .6 mm thinnest layer. I understand you may want to get that as thin as possible for your nozzle/printer.

It contain a new tube for spool holder, a big nut for spool locking, an extension tube for multiple spools mount and a new support.
Note that the new support is partially unstable and shake a little bit when your printer is running.

If you are using different slicer try to find similar option and then check it in layer view.

description.text:
Lego technic power function connector

This connector retrieves the electrical signals from the remote control unit to add new functions.

In my example, I added LEDs that light up in the headlights when the engine is running.

Manual:

  • print the piece
  • pass small rigid wires (telephone or network cable types) in the holes
  • fold them on each side of the connector
  • solder a test plate on the other side

Lego technic power function connecteur

Ce connecteur permet de récupérer les signaux électriques du bloc télécommande pour ajouter de nouvelles fonctions.

Dans mon exemple, j'ai ajouté des LED qui s'allument dans les phares lorsque le moteutr tourne.

Mode d'emploi:

  • imprimer la pièce
  • passer des petits fils rigides (types cable téléphonique ou réseau) dans les trous
  • les plier de chaque côté du connecteur
  • souder une plaque d'essais de l'autre côté
8 Ports (and 80 watts) of USB charging, conveniently attached right to the wall with a table to easily handle several charging devices.

3D Printed Parts

Print w/Supports

  • 1x - Edge_Left.stl
  • 1x - Edge_Right.stl
  • 1x - USB_Mount_Left.stl
  • 1x - USB_Mount_Right.stl

No Supports required

  • 1x - Corner_Brace_Left.stl
  • 1x - Corner_Brace_Right.stl
  • 2x - Back_Lip.stl

Optional

  • 1x - jig1.stl -- used during assembly
Laser Cut Parts
  • 1x - top_platform.dxf
  • 1x - middle_platform.dxf
  • 1x - bottom_platform.dxf
  • 1x - spine.dxf (includes 2 spines)

Wood Thickness - 1/4" (or 5.7mm). I used Red Oak for the top and MDF for middle, bottom, and spines.

Other Parts
  • 2x - iClever Boostcube+ 40W 4-Port USB Wall Charger
  • 1x - Figure 8 Shotgun Connector AC Power Cord
  • 1x - C8 Type Power Socket Connector
  • 2x - M3x30mm flat-top screws
  • 2x - M3x20mm flat-top screws
  • 2x - M3x16 (or 20mm) screws
  • 6x - M3 hex nuts
  • 6x - 1/2" length wood screws
  • 5/8" square dowel -- 323mm long
  • 2x - drywall screws (and anchors, if needed)
  • 18 gauge hookup wire
  • Solder

Glue together Platforms
  • Align and glue together the TOP, MIDDLE, and BOTTOM platforms, using the USB charger holes and screw holes to make sure everything is properly aligned.
  • Clamp together and allow to dry
  • Glue the 2 spine pieces together and clamp
  • Once all is dry, you can glue and clamp the spine to the platform and allow to dry.
Prepare the USB chargers

To make it easy to wire up the USB chargers, we will need to pop off & remove the bottom gray portion of the charger that has the plug.

Do the following for both chargers:

  • Use a small flathead screwdriver, and begin to pry and break the glue that holds the gray plug portion of the USB charger from the outer white walls.
  • Take your time and slowly pry... once the entire perimeter has been separated, the gray plug portion will pop out with a little prying force.
  • Using a pair of wire cutters, cut the wire closet to the plug leaving the remaining length intact.

See picture of disassembled charger for more details

Wiring the USB Chargers

This section will require that you're handy with a soldering iron.

  • Solder a small length of wires to the power socket connector.
  • Run the wires from the power socket into the Left USB Mount and out of the hole on the mount, leaving exposed so we can wire up the chargers later.
  • Insert 2x M3 nuts into the left mount to secure the power socket with 2x M3x16mm screws.
  • You will need to extend the wires from the chargers. Cut small lengths of 2 different color wires (e.g. white, black) and use to extend the charger's wires.
  • Do this for both chargers, using the same color wires on each charger.
  • Push both USB Chargers into each hole in the platforms. Make sure to place the chargers in the same direction so cables all plug in the same direction.
  • Place the USB Mounts over the Chargers and route the wires through the holes on the mounts.
  • Run the wires from the USB mount (w/o the A/C power plug) through the holes in the spine
  • Now you will join the wires together for each pole. (e.g. all black wires together and all white wires together)
  • Once everything is wired up, plug it in and confirm it works. Then use 2x wood screws, per mount, to secure the mounts to the platform

I used shrink wrap tubing to keep all wires protected and looking neat/tidy. Additionally, I used a small bead of glue on each charger/mount to fully secure the charger in place.

Final Assembly
  • Insert the Edge Left and Edge Right pieces into the platform. The extrusion from the edge pieces will fit into the slot of the platform (between the top/bottom pieces).
  • Use 2x M3x20mm flathead screws into the front of the platform to secure the edge pieces to the platform with 2x M3 nuts.
  • Put the square dowel in place along the back of the shelf.
  • Insert 2x M3 nuts into the Corner Brace parts.
  • Align the Corner Brace pieces with the holes in the shelf. Use 2x M3x30mm screws to secure the braces with the platform.
  • With the dowel still in place, use a pencil to mark the center spots of the cut-outs on the bottom platform. This is where you will drill holes for mounting.
  • If you printed the optional jig1.stl piece, use this on the dowel to locate the center. Drill a hole all the way through for both of the spots you marked.

You're now ready to hang the shelf

Hanging the Shelf
  • With the dowel still inserted in the shelf, find the spot where you want to mount the shelf. Pick a place that can easily access power.
  • Once your spot is picked, use a pencil to draw a line under the dowel.
  • Now remove the dowel and align it to your mark on the wall and mark the holes on the wall.
  • Drill holes and attach the dowel to the wall. Use wall anchors if you aren't attaching to studs
  • Slide the shelf into the dowel and use 2x wood screws to attach the Corner Braces to the dowel. This will lock the shelf in place.

Happy Convenient Charging!!

description.text:
Hello All,

Not bad for a day's work. This is the first draft of my custom dials for my Xwing set. I will eventually get to most of the ships, but since I don't collect or play imperials very much, they will probably come last (sorry imps). I can do requests, if people like. They're not that hard to edit, now I've got the process down pat.

For now, the main body of the dial (dial base) needs to be flipped, so the flat (top) is touching the build plate. I'll get to flipping that in the future.

For all of mine, in the pics, I have cut about 1.5/2mm off of the dial base's height (large flat part), as when you add the picture cutout it adds another 1mm.

C&C welcome,
Alex

http://youtu.be/PSwfhPHeCR4 Download the model:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:273805
(The Prusa_i3_X_End_Motor.stl is copied from
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39889/#files)
  • Parts:
    • AutoLevel_Z_EndStopMount.stl x1
    • LM8UU x1
    • Screws M3-15mm x1
    • Screws M3-5mm x1
    • Screws M2-8mm x2
    • Nut M3 x1
    • Nut M5 x1
    • Just like the "X End motor mount ", Use a M5 nut to pull up/down the end-stop-mount. But need use a M3-5mm screw to fix the M5 nut with it. M3-15mm and the M3 nut is used to grip the LM8UU in the center clamp. Directly use the original Z End-Stop micro switch as the detect switch shows in the figure. Adjust the touch screw of X end motor mount to "just" press the Z End-Stop Switch. When move down Z direction and J-Head hit the bed, X would stop move down, but Z End-Stop Mount wont stop and the micro switch would be released. By this way, Marlin can detect the nozzle already hit the bed. Use Marlin "Bed Auto Leveling, grid mode"
    https://github.com/ErikZalm/Marlin Edit the configuration.h file.
    https://github.com/ErikZalm/Marlin/blob/Marlin_v1/Marlin/Configuration.h

  • Invert your Z min end-stop setting. Originally, Z min end-stop is hit when Z at home position, But this design let it release when Z at home.

    • const bool Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false;

  • Active auto leveling by delete "//" before

    • #define ENABLE_AUTO_BED_LEVELING

  • Update these setting for the rectangle in which to probe

    • #define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 0
    • #define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 120
    • #define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 150
    • #define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 50

  • Set the number of grid points per dimension. I wouldn't see a reason to go above 3 (=9 probing points on the bed)

    • #define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS 3

  • These are the offsets to the probe relative to the extruder tip (Hotend - Probe)
    Because directly use J-head to probe bed level, offset of X and Y should be zero. The offset of Z direction need to check up by exam, we set to zero in the first time.

    • #define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0
    • #define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0
    • #define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

  • Burn Marlin into RAMPS system.

  • Execute these G code for first level detect.

    • G28 X
    • G28 Y
    • G28 Z
    • G29
    • G1 Z10
    • G1 X100 Y100

  • Check the Z offset
    Put an A4 paper on print bed, and lower Z 0.1mm once a step until J-head just bites the paper and can't move the paper easily. At this time, READ the Z POSITION FROM LCD. This reading is your offset of Z direction.

  • Update the Z offset (Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER) and burn Marlin into RAMPS again.

  • (optional) Do "Restore Failsafe" in LCD if there are old config setting in EEPROM.

  • Update "Ptr G-code -> Prefix" in KISSlicer
    M104 S
    G28 X
    G28 Y
    G28 Z
    G29; Detailed Z-Probe
    G1 Z3
    G1 X100 Y200 F3000
    G1 Z0
    M109 S
    • After all, enjoy the convenience of Auto Bed Leveling!

comments.text: Sorry, but this design is simple and works but it will ruin your hot bed surface. Neither the nozzle on the extruder nor the hotbed are designed to be pressed down against each other like that. Especially when they're hot. You will eventually end up with a warped or damaged part. I use a polycarbonate sheet on my hot bed so pressing an 200°C extruder nozzle on it over and over again is definitely a no go. Not to mention that it will leave traces of melted filament all over the place.

Update....all working......just one one captive nut on end stop carrier (yellow), no nut on X motor assembly (blue part)
Problems.....the print was initially too high on left table, and so low on right the head touched the glass. Seems to be due to the sprung table, and the mechanical advantage of the x motor idler on the right --- also mentioned previously.

comments.text: No I do not think so! You have to have M5 nut in both the X motor mount and auto level mount! Both slide up-down together on Z threaded rod. The point is, that when your head touches the glass, X motor mount will start to LIFT itself from the nut, thus raise the screw pressing down on the microswitch in autolevel.

comments.author: alien2108

comments.text:
What I do is....first.......use Repetier to "manually" heat the head to 210c and bed to 60c. I then leave it for 5 mins so that the goo drains out of the head. I use Cura to print...and AFTER the G Code in start code for the leveling (G28, G29 etc) there is a command G1 F200 E3, to exude 3mm of filament in order to charge the head before it starts the print. As my head is now empty, I increase the E3 to E30 (30mm of filament)...This is more than enough to fill the empty head. So....no blobs on the leveling cos at that point we have no goo in head !!!!!!!!!
Hope this helps......if you don't use Cura, the same idea will obviously still work if you insert a E30 code after the leveling.
comments.author: alien2108

comments.text: Probe before heating and keep in mind that your nozzle might enlarge a bit after the heating. Therefore, if your nozzle is too far away after probing, try to reduce the Z offset. Also be sure to always to probing in "cool" state (under 100°C for me).

G28 X ; home all axes

comments.text:
To check that the Z value is correct:
Burn the Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER value onto your machine.
Then, do a G28 and G29 (auto bed leveling) and do a G1 Z0.3.
This should result into having the hotend nozzle just above your bed. If this is not the case, your Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER value is wrong.

comments.text:
Hello crota, I'm going to try to do a question because I don't speak good english. Before you use your autoleveling piece, x-idler and x-motor end have an M5 nut. So they rest on these nuts in order to be able to go up and down by means of both Z stepper motors.
Once you use your piece, you need to remove the x-motor end nut, since the x-motor end rests on your piece and is your piece who moves it up or down. The question is: what happens with the x-idler? Do you remove it's M5 nut? If you remove the x-idler nut it seems that you force the X axe because you are moving it with only one of the Z steppers. If you don't remove the x-idler M5 nut, it seems that you to force the X axe with the bed when the nozzle touches it.

comments.text: Sorry, there is a misunderstanding. I didn't remove the M5 nuts in X_end_Motor, neither X_end_Idler. Z axis move up/down still by those two M5 nuts.

comments.text: I also don't get it. This level the bed on the z axis threaded rod? How is this linked to the bed. How does extruder touch the bed? The endstop is on the z-axis, not the extruders actual height. This would only auto level the same position on the z threaded rod over and over again
comments.author: DeanR

comments.text: The whole X carriage assembly is resting on top of the z end-stop. The weight of the carriage is holding the end-stop in the depressed position. The end-stop is wired to make connection on release, instead of the usual way which makes contact on press. When the weight of the carriage is supported by the nozzle touching the bed instead, the end-stop no longer needs to support the carriage and so releases, breaking contact.

title: Monoprice Select Mini V2 X End Cap Puller

description.text:
The X arm end cap on my latest Mini v2 was (as it turns out) glued on to the shafts and I wasn't able to budge it using the usual hammer method. So I quickly designed this puller to remove the end cap.

Ended up with 2 versions, the first with an M3 screw, and a larger one with M4 when I destroyed the M3 screw and nut on the first one from over torque trying to move the stronger glued shaft of the pair.

What you will need:

2 prints of the puller (either 2 of one size or one of each of both sizes)
2 socket cap screws and nuts for the size of pullers you printed (Screws will need to be a minimum of 20mm long, I would recommend 25mm)
Good quality allen key(s) for the size of screws you used (something that won't explode when reffing on it)
(M4 version only) 4mm drill bit
(optional) Pliers

Note on the M3 version:

The torque needed to break the cap free may be very high and can exceed what a regular M3 is rated.
M3 hardware will likely be ruined after use. Dispose of M3 hardware after use to save yourself headache later.

Recommendation:

If you have M4 hardware, a 4mm drill bit, and don't mind widening a couple holes on your printer, I would use the M4 version and skip trying the M3 one first.

Setup:

Fit a nut in to the puller and full seat it. The nut hole is designed to be a push fit, use pliers might be helpful.
If using the M4 version, widen the holes on the end cap at the shaft ends.
The pullers are designed to fit over the top and bottom of the end cap and slot in to place (see pictures)
Fit screws in to each pull and make sure they feed in to the holes on the end cap.

Usage:

Carefully tighten each one slowly, alternating back and forth.
It may take a good amount of torque before the end cap starts to move.
Be careful as mine took a lot of force for a small plastic part to budge at first. If your's is glued as well, it may suddenly make a loud snap sound as it first breaks free and starts to move.
If using only 20mm long screws, you will not be able to use the pulls to fully remove the end cap, but once a full depth, you should be able to yank it free with your bear hands.
Bear hands not included.

After removal:

If yours was glued on like mine, I would suggest scraping and cleaning off all the glue left on the shafts before removing the printhead carriage.

Fusion file:

Can't export as file due to current Fusion limitation on linked designs
http://a360.co/2CbZMBH

Printer:

MPSMv2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

80%

Notes:

Print for strength. PLA worked. ABS may also work. PETG might be too flexible.

I used:
4-5 shell
3 layers top/bottom
80-90% infill using triangle and zigzag patterns
High end temps for my PLA (220C from its normal 215C)
105% extrusion flow

title: 31.75mm adapter for C270 Webcam for astrophotography
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
English Version

This adapter is made to replace the original webcam's cover to allow it to fit directly into the focuser of a telescope. Let's do some planetary imaging !

How to use it

  1. Print the two pieces without support.
  2. Unclip the gray cover of the webcam.
  3. Unscrew the black faceplate to open the case, keep the little screws.
  4. Remove the lens .
  5. Screw the printed faceplate with the original screws.
  6. With three 6mm M3 screws, assemble the focuser adapter.
  7. Use the logitech software to switch off the green LED inside the webcam.

The sky is yours !

Version française

Cet adaptateur vient en remplacement de la facade du boitier d'origine pour vous permettre d'utiliser votre webcam Logitech C270 pour faire de l'astrophoto planétaire. Elle pourra ainsi s'adapter sur un coulant 31.75mm.

Comment l'utiliser

  1. Imprimez les deux pièces sans support.
  2. Déclippez la face avant grise.
  3. Vous pouvez maintenant dévisser le couvercle noir. Gardez bien les petites vis.
  4. Retirez la lentille.
  5. Vissez la partie plate imprimée avec les vis d'origine.
  6. Avec 3 vis M3 de 6mm, assemblez l'adaptateur coulant 31.75mm
  7. Utilisez le logiciel fourni par Logitech pour désactiver la LED verte de fonctionnement.

Le ciel est maintenant à vous !

author: C3customsllc

title: Big DIY 3D printer 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Big DIY 3D printer 2

This 3D printer is a modification of the Big DIY 3D Printer. I decided to make a new thing of it because I changed so much.
The idea of this printer is to make it with materials you already have to keep it cheap.
Basically a 3D printer is an X, Y and Z axis. This model is an X and Y axis that can be brought up as high as you want, and so making it bigger on the Z axis. In my example I made an Z axis from extruded aluminum lengths (30x33mm) and 608Z bearings I had. I included the files for the Z axis also if you want to make the Z axis this way. The X and Y axis can also be made as long as you want. The length is determent by the length of 10mm rods you use. My rods are 1000mm long. In my case that means the maximum length of X and Y are 835mm by 710mm. My Z hight is 680mm at the moment because the aluminum lengths I have are not any longer. But If they where I would make the Z axis 2 meter :-) .

But the reason for the upgrade is that a big printer has it's issues. Printing big objects means that it will take a lot of time. So you want to speed it up. But then vibrations and sound will be much stronger. Also the longer your rods are the more vibrations you will get. (I'm thinking of using these carbon fiber ones because they are much stiffer, they say). So to make these effects less, I made this much lighter X axis and X car setup. Now the X car can move much faster with less vibrations. With PLA and PET-G this setup works much better than the old one. I removed the geared extruder from the X car to the side using a DIY “Bowden setup”.
On the X car I only have a hot end and fans now. The fan brackets in red ABS are not of my own design but from RoPa here on Thingiverse : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1264477. I like this design and it fit's this minimalistic setup :-) .

The controller and firmware are still the same as with Big DIY 3D printer. If you are interested in that please visit :
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2603668

To reduce vibrations and noise I experimented with a DIY vibration “dampeners” made out of silicon.
I cut these silicon “dampeners” out of a baking mat bought in a cheap Chinese products store.
The Yellow plastic peace is my template for cutting the once for the motors.
I know there are still direct contact areas from the motors to the rest of the printer frame. I didn’t fully isolate the mounting bolts.
But for now the results are good. There is much less noise and vibrations and the print is good. :-)

Update Jan-06-2018 :
The point where the timing belt was connected broke :-(

So I made this alternative repair part :-)

Also the original part is slightly modified. But If you got your one broken also this repair part may come in handy. I called the part “timing belt mounting point broken repair part1A & B.STL. Also the additional picture may explain more :-).

Feb-06-2018 :Geared Extruder Update
included file: geard extruder STLs.ZIP

I made a new Extruder for this super DIY “bowden setup” :-).
My aim was to make it simple, strong and that the filament could be pressed super hard against the driver gear. Filament can be guided with a adjustable guide. For now I kept the gland nut, but included parts that can be adjusted for regular Teflon tube holders. On the printer on the pictures the gland nut works really well. This extruder en tube setup has made the print test of 20 hours. But on another printer of mine the gland nut works not so good. It's because that one prints with much higher speeds (60mm/s and higher) and than the gland nut does not hold so good anymore. I found that it does help to put Katon tape one the tube :-) I am still experimenting with other tube holder methods :-)
The little filament driver (11mm diameter) is mounted on an M8x50mm bolt I had lying around. On the lathe I turned the end of this M8 bolt down to 5mm so the driver can be mounted on it. See pictures

Teflon tube holder upgrade FEB-20-2018 update

This upgrade is about replacing the gland nut for tube holder clips. See pictures
Experimenting with these clips I came to the understanding that the diameter of the hole where the clip is placed in is very important. Because not all Teflon tubes are the same size the diameter of this hole can be different. The Teflon tubing I have is between 3 – 4 mm. So for me it works best that to bore out the hole with a 6.5mm. But I recommend to begin with 6mm. If that is too tight, bore 6.5mm and so on.

If you have any questions feel free to ask :-)

Parts list for the X Y & Hot End setup:

6X F625ZZ bearing wheel
6X 623Z bearing
4X LM10UU/SP linear bearing
4X SCS10UU linear bearing
4X xxx length x10mm gliding rod
3X Nema 17 Stepper Motor
3X Timing belt pulley and matching timing belts
2X End Switch
Bowden Extruder Setup
Hot End & wires

19X M5x30mm bolt
3X M5 nut
3X M4x40mm bolt
4X M4x20mm bolt
4X M4x10mm bolt
15X M4 nut
30X M3x10mm bolt
4X M3x20mm bolt
2X M3x40mm bolt
27X M3 nut

For the Z axis setup you need:
16X 608ZZ bearing
1X end switch
16X M8 bolt or threaded rod 8mm and nuts
2X spindle 8mm and spindle nut or M8 threaded rod and nut
2X stepper Nema 17
2X motor to spindle connector 5mm to 8mm
6X M4x40mm bolt
6X M4 nut
8X M3x10mm bolt
8x M3x20mm bolt and nuts are optional if you use the M8 converter part.
1X heat bed and power supply that can deliver the current (I have a 12V /360W)

For the Controller You need:

1X Arduino Mega
1X Ramps 1.4 board and Full graphic smart controller
6X stepper driver A4988 or DRV8825 (you will have to hack your ramps to install all of them :-) )
1X 12V/240W power supply (I have a 360W)
1X opto coupler and FET for switching the heat bed (you can buy them as a board)
1X fan to cool the drivers (I have an 80 x 80 mm)

the blue and green parts are printed in PET-G resolution 0,2mm

comments.text: Nice big printer!  I made a big printer also 400 mm cube print surface. To fix the noise problem, I am using 0.9 degree motors, and 32 bit board. The main board I am using is RE-ARM from Panucatt Devices, but I suggest that you use the smoothieboard instead (if you want to go the 32 bit way). Also I am using DM542 microstep drivers that can go up to 25600 microsteps per revolution. I also have Aluminium Cooling Fin Heat Sinks on the motors with fans to keep them cold/warm, because I am pushing the motors beyond ratings :) The fans make more noise than the motors when it's printing at medium speed.

title: Orange Pi PC Plus 60 mm fan case

description.text:
This is a case for use with Orange Pi PC Plus.
It utilizes a 60x60x15 mm fan to keep things cool with low noise levels.

The GPIO pins are completely inaccessible and the connection for the fan needs to be soldered
directly to the input power pins.

This OPi case will be abandoned and a case with a radial fan will be developed, figured it'd be good to share this case as it might inspire others, and a lot of folks have shown interest in this case when sharing it previously.

One needs the following parts:
4 pcs M3x30 insex screws
4 pcs M3 nuts

Here are the electronic parts needed for this project:
Orange Pi PC Plus
Orange Pi Heatsinks
60mm fan
RP-SMA Antenna Adapter
2.4Ghz Antenna

description.text:
I'v made this snowflake puzzle inspired on an old puzzle I saw on the internet.

You need to print
Part 1 3x
Part 2 5x
Part 3 1x

Solution: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RBLi2pMRrtY

Edit this project at BlocksCAD: https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor?from=68124
Or, download the .xml file and load it at: https://www.blockscad3d.com/editor

Disclaimer:
This is NOT my design I recreated it from an old puzzle I saw on the internet so you can 3d print your own now
I made the model because I liked the puzzle but could not find any model of the puzzle so I wanted to create my own and because it is a sort of snowflake I thought I make it in BlocksCad and join the challenge.

Printer:

Builder Mono

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 Micron

Infill:

20%

Step 1: I made a simple rectangle and removed two blocks so I got this shape Step 2: I copied it and moved using the loop function Step 3: For the "pointy" pieces I did the same as step two but made the rectangle a little shorter Step 4: I added a square and used the Pythagorean theorem to connect the square to the main piece Step 5: I copied the point piece on te other side and mirrored it Step 6: I copied it and moved using the loop function Step 7: for the piece with the thin middle I just did the same as step 3, 4 and 5 but removed one more piece Step 8: when I had every part I placed al the pieces into one project

Cura and other slicers are more tolerant handling that issue.

title: CR-10 E3D V6 Cooling Unit NEW (Release 2)

description.text:
New release of over-worked first design. This one (R2) has even more cooling power and cools enough for a sharp single perimeter pyramid tip!
The fans provide 6mm more room on each side for cables and air circulation.
The openings of the funnels have asymmetrical characteristics to the nozzle: They blow before and after, or left and right.. (depending on the nozzle moves). In this way, the two air streams don't work against each other, further giving a chance to establish a more vortex like air flow. Screw area is now beefed up a bit (you need longer screws now). The center plate is the same (R2) as in the old package.

Print the funnels with fan surface down to the table, use support for clean arms. Print the center plate with back side down to the table, also use support for the overhang area.
Funnels: Drill the holes for the fans 2.5mm in diameter and use 3mm screws. I printed my stuff in ABS, in order to prevent melting over a very hot bed.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

author: Splund

description.text:
This is another remix of Kirbs' Flexi Rex, based on airfish's remix. That model in turn was most likely inspired by the Flexy Rex by zheng3.

My print of Kirbs' model was not very kid-proof: one of the links broke after some rough handling. Hence I made all links more robust. This means this model can probably be printed even smaller than the original ones before the links become too weak. Of course you can also scale it up at will.

If you want to make a dual extrusion print like this one from Adafruit, check out the remix by AndrewSink.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed with 3 perimeters for more strength. No supports needed.
This should move freely right after you take it off the build plate. If you print with hairspray on a glass bed, the Rex should spontaneously jump into a random pose all by itself when it pops off the plate after cooling down. If you need to use force to free the hinges, you still have some optimization work to do on your printing technique.

comments.author: DrLex

comments.text: Well, stringing is usually the least of these problems, and I also have problems eliminating it with certain types of PLA in an all-metal hot-end. If you wiggle the parts around, and poke in between the gaps with a needle, you can usually break the strings easily. A quick pass with a hot air gun can also help to remove the strings (but be careful not to melt everything!)

author: AnasAlam

print_settings.Resolution:: As small as your printer goes
print_settings.Notes:: The important note is, you only really see the top of the foot when it's on the Valkyrie, so print so that looks best

description.text:
Hello All,

I had misplaced some of my Valkyrie landing gear. So I designed my own, instead of buying more. The smaller middle landing gears will be added at some point in the future (when I cba lol)

I've broken the gear up into a few smaller pieces, dunno if that will help anyone at all. I just printed the thing whole, worked well enough.

As mentioned in the printing instructions, this needs supports (unless you cut it, I guess) The top of the feet are the only bit that really gets seen, so aim to have that the prettiest part if you can (I haven't tried printing it rotated so the detail is in the "Z" dimension, that's probably best)

If printing two, just mirror the original. The top part, where it attaches to the Valkyrie is slightly different on each side, so a tiny amount of cutting is required, but it's very minimal.

Enjoy, hope someone finds this useful. C&C welcome,
Alex

EDIT 1: added a test for the missile mount

description.text:
Whilst preparing for the sequel to my popular YouTube video on silencing the CR-10 (https://youtu.be/Vlta31wswAE), I designed these feet for the CR-10 range to dampen noise from vibrations against the table surface.

They make a difference and keep the printer really nice and stable.

I hope you enjoy printing and using my design. To help me keep designing and uploading more things, as well as continue to run my YouTube channel (www.youtube.com/c/3drevolution), please consider making a small donation to me via PayPal: www.paypal.me/JoshForwood
Thank you!

This is designed to be printed in a flexible filament such as flexible PLA or ninjaflex.

For the infill, if you have S3D, set it to 5% from the bottom up until 5 layers before the base of the "cup" begins (where the printers built in foot will sit), at which point set it to 10%.

If you can't adjust the infill at different layer heights, I'd recommend trying 10% all the way through and seeing how you find it.

description.text:
*Update - I found this to be fine on half spools but when the spool is full could do be with being a bit longer. Extended by 20mm v5 uploaded- also added some more depth to the hole for the PTFE tube.

I wanted to tidy up the feed into the Bowden drive so made this, Thought I would share

The first one was for a 4mm Pneumatic fitting, but the brass edge shaved the filament as it fed in.

So I glued in a plastic coupling instead but hated the Botch job

Remade with a built-in feed hole. and made it longer.
Also, the 4mm PTFE tube fits in nicely without any glue or need for a mechanical fitting

Could still do with being another 30mm longer, when I get round to it will update.

Drawn up in Fusion 360

author: Wassili1972

description.text: My Hama Star 5 tripod got a part that broke. The replacement works great.

A flat pattern that can be scrunched into shallow conical rings which approximate a parabolic reflector (focuses far-away light sources into a small area). Focal length and diameter are both about 11".

Cut this pattern out of something shiny and flexible, like thin mirrored acrylic or metalized plastic film. Then tape the two ends of each arc together, which will pull the flat arc into a shallow cone.
If your material is too flexible you can cut out some backing pieces out of a cereal box or something similar using the same flat pattern. If it is not flexible enough, you'll have a hard time pulling the pieces into cones.
Tape or hot-glue the rings to a backing board to keep them all lined up and concentric. Mine gives me about a 3/4" wide focus blob. This works best when your target object can be put on a stick, so you can hold it out over the reflector without blocking the light with your hand and arm.

description.text: NOW WITH INDUCTIVE CHARGING This is a bike mount for the Google Nexus 5 Smartphone for use on the handlebar stem on a Giant Escape 3. It should be useable on other Giant bikes however I have not tested any other bikes. The mount is attached to the stem using zipties, it is reccomended to apply some electrical tape to the contact surface to prevent wriggle. IMPORTANT: Made for naked Nexus 5 with or without a screen protector. The current version is a bit tight, I will upload a second version with a better fit as soon as I have tested it out. EDIT*: Uploaded version 2 with a slightly looser fit to prevent scratching. Still secure though! EDIT2*: Uploaded version 3 with built in inductive charging capabilities! Of course you may have to change the dimensions slightly to accomodate different QI coils. I got rid of the tab as there was no space for it. As of now, the phone fits snugly so it shouldn't slip off.

Printed the file with support on a Makerbot 2 using:
8% Fill
2 Shells
0.3mm Layer Height Use zipties to mount onto the bike. Also if it isn't already obvious, rotate the object such that the "nexus" text is upright.

comments.text:

I printed it standing up (the word nexus can be read normally) but I used support because of the top thingy that holds the phone. But it had support inside the zip tie holes which is impossible to remove.
So I guess, no support should be used.

title: Dom toren / Dom Tower (Utrecht, The Netherlands)

description.text:
The Dom Tower (Cathedral Tower, Dutch: Domtoren) of Utrecht is the tallest church tower in the Netherlands, at 112.5 metres (368 feet) in height, and the Gothic-style tower is the symbol of the city. The tower was part of the Cathedral of Saint Martin, Utrecht, also known as Dom Church, and was built between 1321 and 1382, to a design by John of Hainaut. The cathedral was never fully completed due to lack of money. Since the unfinished nave collapsed in 1674 the Dom tower became a free standing tower.

The tower stands at the spot where the city of Utrecht originated almost 2,000 years ago.

source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/dom_tower_of_utrecht

title: 3D printed lampshade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple lampshade I designed and printed using "spiral vase mode" or "spiralize outer contour" as it is known in Cura. Make sure to disable top and bottom layers and ad some brim if you feel that it is necessary.

The hole in the centre of the mounting piece is 28 mm in diameter. I am not sure if it is a standard that fits any other lamps than the one I have. But even if it does not fit, you can still use my design as inspiration and create something similar. The lampshade itself is 14 cm high and 10 cm in diameter.

Video: https://youtu.be/ln-41IiYy_8

Skip to the end of the video for the result.

Update 2018-01-09
Added another version of the lampshade with a more rounded shape.

author: lbroman

title: Street Sport Rear Axle (inner half only)

description.text:
Woe is me.

I put in a bigger battery. With more battery comes more power. With more power comes more problems. I suppose I am continuing to find all the weak spots in my Traxxas Street Sport. Yesterday, it sheared (absolutely exploded) the inner axle.

So, in response, I made this!

You'll find an A version and a B version. The C version was a vertically oriented one, but you probably couldn't fit the steel yolk into the joint without shattering the part. A and B are just in two different orientations and are otherwise (nearly) identical. (I think one of them picked up a little artifact while I was adjusting it).

I tested a rough draft of this yesterday, but at the very end of the drive, as I beckoned for the car to approach me, the test one exploded. I'm trying out a few improvements in these items, such as making the base of the joint significantly thicker (I have the room, why not?).

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

PowerSpec 3D Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

There will be some work required to make this work. You'll need a file, but that's about it. Maybe sand paper, but you'll have some material to remove and the file will chew through nicely. What's that, you say? You have a belt sander? Even better! Use that instead!

Right. What do you have to file (or beltsand)? The square output where the axle slides into the outer axle shaft. You want that to be smooth as glass. The way at least my printer works, it won't be off the printer, so this part might be a tad large to allow you to file it. You'll also want to file the inside of the joint where the steel joint thing interfaces.

The idea came to me in a dream. There I was, standing on top of a mountain, surveying all that lay before me. Suddenly, the ground beneath me began to shake. A rift opened before me, and out of the rift arose an enormous, perfectly-smooth rock. The rock split in half with a great boom, and inside the rock was a slightly smaller, smoother rock. That fell off the broken rock's rubble pile and rolled towards me. Then it split, but with a much softer boom. Inside that rock was a gold rose petal.

I woke immediately and knew what had to be done.

title: Wemos ESP8266 with DS18B20 sensor enclosure

description.text:
Hi mates!

Here is the story of this design:

ESP8266 (Wemos) are nice little things in the IoT world...so I decided to use them in order to get and control all my house rooms temperature. So ESP8266 collects tempature then send them to a hub (a raspberry 3) via Wifi...Then I use a franco-french technology (referred to as Fil pilote) to activate/desactivate heaters in all rooms...ok everything works fine but I needed an enclosure to wrap the ESP8266 (Wemos) and the temp sensor : DS18B20.
A lot of design exists on thingiverse ... But most of them does not meet
this particular expectation :

Even if my ESP8266 is in deep sleep most of the time, it must be isolated as much as possible from the temp sensor so it does not interfer with it. This design addresses this particular issue because:

  • ESP8266 is well separated from sensor and higher than the sensor is the enclosure so even small warm generated will not interfer.
  • Sensor is below and well aerated

And voila :)

Special thanks to Le Bear CNC (your Fusion 360 tutorials are greats)

My daughter got some tupperware ECO bottles for school, but these were only with the drinking cap, which is not usable for water with gas as the pressure opens the cap and the liquid will flow out of the bottle.
So I decided to design a cap for the tupperware ECO. I made it for the german version (500ml), but on the bottle there is a stamp which says 16oz. Because of that I am of the opinion, that you can use the cap in the US too.
Don't use PLA! PLA is not flexible enough and also will get soft in the dishwasher! Always use material wich complies to the Regulation on Plastic Food Contact Materials!
I recomment PETG from extrudr.
The design regars the FFF process and has an optimal fit: it is easy to screw and a thight fit.

Printer:

helloBEEprusa

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,05 mm - 0,1 mm

Infill:

25% - 100%

Notes:

Print it with the closed face down! Otherwise you need support and the cap will not close the bottle as the surface is rough!
Because of the thread, you have to print it at least with 0,1mm layerheight. Better is 0,05mm.
Don't use PLA! PLA is not flexible enough and will get soft in the dishwasher! Always use material wich complies to the Regulation on Plastic Food Contact Materials!
I recomment PETG from extrudr.
The design regars the FFF process and has an optimal fit: it is easy to screw and a has thight fit.

Cleanup after printing

You should cleanup the thread after printing for easy use. If it's too rough, it will hurt the plastic of the bottle. I sanded the thread a little bit at the end (just 1 to 2 rounds) and washed the cap with a toothbrush.

title: HTC Vive HMD mount (under desk)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed this mount so I could hang my Vive headset from the underside of my desk.

The left and right bracket are symmetrical and made to closely follow the contours of the headset.

When the brackets are placed the correct distance apart the headset is held low enough that the menu button isn't pressed. To position the brackets and holes accurately I've included a 1:1 paper template.

While it's not a necessity I decided to stick 1.5mm thick neoprene foam on the arms of the brackets (using double-sided carpet tape) to cushion the headset.

author: MassassiOrder

title: 1:700 USN Merchants Set 1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My first love in gaming is Naval Miniatures - of all the baordgames, RPGs and miniatures games I was presented as a nube back in the day, this was first introduction to gaming in general. Thanks to some stranger that walked into the club that I found, the gent had a box load of 1:1250 WW2 naval minis and a copy of Seakrieg. Over forty years later, I can now design and lasercut my own. Hoping to trial these out with either Fast Attack or Fletcher Pratt rules in the near future. I will be releasing other sets as time permits. Meant to be cut at 300DPI for raster resolution, as per all my lasercut file patterns. Otherwise, follow any other advice listed below.

In this current set I present in order of appearance USN Type C1-A, C1-B, Liberty and Victory ships. The last two have optional masts, if you want to install forward port/starboard MG nests. I have keyed the bits together with tracelines or you'll just have to look at the provided photos to figure out what pieces fit where. You will have to buy/cut/size your own dowel for funnels - available at your typical hardware or dollarstore and I assemble these vessels using carpenters glue. Have fun. Lifeboats are missing from the Liberty and Victory ships presented, as I had the wrong cut line on the original test pattern, yours should work fine. These are meant to be representative of each class, based on key features and not neccessarily 100% historically accurate, and no two ships where probably exactly the same anyway, so they are offered as is.

Formatted for cutting on a combination of 6mm, 3mm MDF and 1-1.5mm cardstock sized to 12" x 9" (Arch A) sheet. Alternatively, you may use any of four quarters on an Arch C (24"x18") board - the size that fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix (what I use). Sheet has a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

title: Boldclash BWhoop B06 Cam- and Board - Holders

description.text:
This is a camera holder for the "Banggood 700TVL 1.8mm 170° 3.7-5V 2,34g" camera and a board holder for the Fishpepper TinyFISH FC and the TinyPEPPER 4in1 ESC. Both can be used together or standalone.

Because I like the low profile of a whoop and the camera fits nearly perfectly between the ducts where it is protected best and I don't want to work with any foam or hot glue I created this. The camera angle is about 17°. The mass of the cam holder is about 1,2g and the mass of the board holder is about 0,4g.
The board holder has 2mm holes that fit to the BWhoop B06 frame. There are additional spacers needed to hold down the board holder with screws. I made them from a Ø3x2 plastic pipe with about 3 mm length each.
The camera holder is fixed to the front screw hole.

Edit 18/01/01:
I installed a "Beecore OSD 4in1 ESC" and created a Beeper holder that is fixed to the frame to the rear screw hole. The Beeper itself is glued to the Beeper holder.

Have fun.

author: HoNau

description.text:
1. Introduction

    This is made for Bowden type dual extruder system.
    This print-head can make you to set the temperature of two hot-ends
    as 190 – 230℃ at once,
    and can standby over 10 minutes without nozzle blocking. (In the case of PLA+lite6)
    I think it can reduce the total printing time when you want to print something
    with dual nozzle system. (for 2 colored prints or using water soluble filament)
    But, to prevent oozing,
    set the standby temp. to 160℃ or below during the other nozzle is printing.
    Additionally, use ooze shield (distance: 30mm) and set move print-head to Y=5
    before each nozzle change.
    (Can set this at extruder end gcode section in machine settings)
    (ex) G1 Y5 F6000

    Before you use this holder, you should do PID auto-tune(with 70% of blower fan speed),
    and please set blower fan speed to lower than 70% during printing.
    If you don’t do PID auto-tune correctly or set blower fan speed higher than 70%,
    the temperature of nozzles will never reach to 230℃ and more.
    Additionally, you have to adjust each nozzle height from print-bed equally.

    I attached adopter is designed for the print-head holder of Anet A8.
    But as you probably know, if you use Anet A8,
    you have to upgrade your motherboard, power supply and etc. for dual nozzle system.
    You can print adopter yourself or order it to laser cutting service market.
    (Acryl:8mm or Steel:3mm)
    In the case you use other shape of print-head holder,
    you can make suitable one by yourself
    or send me correct information about the size of your print-head holder.
    (picture and distance between holes)
    I will try to make adopter for you.

    I got many useful parts and learned a lot about 3D printer
    from thingiverse and other 3D printer communities.
    I hope this can be useful too.
    I want to make this print-head to injection molding version.
    If you think this print-head is useful enough to you,
    please define its value and support my project.
    I will really appreciate even if you donate just 0.1 dollar.
    If you have any opinions or requirements about this parts,
    please leave message or feel free to contact me by e-mail.
    Thank you and Happy new year!!

Donation address:
https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=42UPBNBEC3PWL

E-mail: [email protected]

  1. Specification

    1) Nozzle: Bowden type E3D V6, LITE6 nozzle
    (or with same radiator size / Can’t use V5)
    2) Front fan size: 50㎜ x 50㎜ x 15㎜ (12v, 0.18A recommended)
    3) Blower fan: 40㎜ x 40㎜
    4) Auto-Leveling sensor: BL-TOUCH, 3D-TOUCH, SN04-N, LJC18A3-B-Z/BY (Selective)
    5) Bolting information
    a) Print head Mounting hole
    o Diameter: M3, 2ea
    o Length of bolt: Depends on thickness of adopter (30 mm+ α)
    o Distance between Holes: 43.8 mm
    b) Nozzle holder
    o M3, 25mm, 1ea
    o M3, 10mm, 2ea
    c) Blower fan holder
    o M3, 20mm, 2ea
    d) Auto leveling sensor adaptor
    o M3, 15mm, 2ea
    e) Auto leveling sensor holder
    o M3, 15mm, 2ea (BL TOUCH, 3D TOUCH)
    6) Distance between Nozzles: 24 mm
    7) Printing condition(PLA)
    a) Nozzle: 0.4mm
    b) Infill: 30%
    c) Wall thickness: 1mm
    d) Supports setting for blower fan holder: Touching build plate (density: 20% or more)

  2. Merits

    1) Dual nozzle holder
    2) Low noise and vibration
    : The fan is separated from each radiator and can use blower fan.
    3) Effective cooling
    : Can standby more than 10 minutes at 210℃ without nozzle blocking
    (In the case of PLA + lite6 nozzle)
    4) Extensive usage
    : Can use any type of Print head holder with adopter
    : Can use various type of Auto-leveling sensor
    5) Easy mounting and nozzle change
    6) Light and simple

  3. Demerits

    1) Wide print-head size
    : It will reduce the size of printable area.
    2) You should do PID Auto-tune correctly.
    : If you don’t, the temperature of nozzle will never reach to 230℃ and more.
    3) You should adjust the distance between heating block and radiator.
    : I recommend to tighten up the nozzle completely to heating block
    and adjust the distance between heating block and radiator to 2 mm.

description.text: This is a simple candle decoration designed to hold some LED candles I bought on Amazon. Granted you have your filament settings tuned in (I did not) this should be a very easy print, albeit a very long one. The overhangs print with no support on my MP Maker V2, which is not a fantastic printer, so you should have no problem. I've only printed it in cheap white PLA so far, which it uses a lot of (this is a long print) but the results would be even better in something really nice like Matterhackers filament on a good machine like a Prusa or Makerbot.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm layer height (can vary based on desire)

Infill:

20% (Doesn't need much at all)

Notes:

Depending on the look you want, you can adjust the number of perimeters- the more opaque you want it (given your filament has some translucency), the more perimeters.

Cleaning up the print

The wells for the candles will likely need to be sanded out a bit to make sure you can get them out easier. If you have a good printer this might not be necessary.

This model was designed in FreeCad as a Christmas gift. The wells are sized perfectly for the Homemory fake flickering candles you can find on Amazon (no affiliation). The model was designed so that no support is necessary, and there is tons of surface area on the bottom so a raft would just be a waste.

description.text:
These pillars (posts, or technically, bridge piers; I learned others call them spacers) have been designed and printed because my son got an amazing new toy from Ravensburger: GraviTrax marble run. And of course, during the holidays, we needed more piers to get the marble run built the way we wanted.. we needed.

So here they are: Extra piers to support the original GraviTrax hexagonal base plates.
Optimized for printing time, not for beautiful design. Needed them desperately!

Update:
My original version without tunnel turned out to be a bit more stable (high marble speeds). So I added them here too.

Links to my other GraviTrax compatible parts:
Tracks: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738473
Curves, Straights, and Joins: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738494
Pendulum ball starter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738573
Magnetic cannon: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738601

Printer:

Anet3d A8-B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Print with big end down! (Use/play with big end at top)

I print them with the Cura settings:

PLA
Wall line count = 3
Top/bottom count = 3

First layer:

  • 0.3mm height at 200% line width
  • 210°C
  • 30mm/s

Remaining layers:

  • 0.2mm height, 0.4mm width (=nozzle diameter)
  • 190°C
  • 60mm/s print speed, except:
  • outer walls: 30mm/s
Play. Maybe some sanding could be required to smoothen the foot (small end) not to brak the original GraviTrax cardboard "play ground"

First real thingi with Fusion 360

As a hobbyist, I downloaded Fusion 360 some time ago and applied for the educational/hobbyist 1-year license. But then almost did nothing with it.

Ravensburger's GraviTrax cried for home made parts, and so I started drafting something like the original pier plates, only 3 times as high. Printed an eternity. We needed more, and faster, so I started a new one only applying plasitc where absolutely needed.

Here you are!
a test

Tour à dés modulaire.
Chaque section peut être montée dans l'ordre qu'on veut (sauf le chapeau et le bas).

Origine et conception

Inspirée de 2 tours présentes sur Thingiverse :

  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1131768
  • https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2640752

Totalement reconstruite avec Sketchup.

Des tétons permettent de positionner et maintenir les sections en place.

Pièces

6 pièces / sections sont disponibles :

  • le Chapeau : c'est le haut de la tour avec les créneaux
  • le Bas : c'est la porte de sortie de dés
  • le Mélangeur : possède une plateforme inclinée pour forcer les dés à changer de direction
  • les Anneaux : ce sont de simples cylindres d'une hauteur donnée en étages de briques (actuellement en 2, 6 et 10 niveaux)

This is a one-piece, wide-mouth canning jar lid that can be printed on a Rep-Rap, Makerbot, or similar 3D printer. I made it to close a jar of hydrochloric acid, which will attack metal but not ABS plastic. The threads work very well.

Print upside-down, with the flat top stuck to your build platform and the threads facing up.  
If it doesn't fully seal the jar, you can try smearing or drizzling a little paraffin wax around the inside edge of the lid, where the jar lip touches.  
Both ABS and paraffin wax have good resistance to hydrochloric acid, which is what I made this lid to contain.

comments.text: When printing with ABS, is there a need to scale the lid to account for shrinkage? For example, most ABS prints recommend printing at 101% scale to account for shrinkage during cooling.

comments.text:
question Why would you NEED Hydrochloric when

comments.author: jjhcs1

comments.text:
They're the same thing. From Wikipedia: "Historically called acidum salis, muriatic acid, and spirits of salt, hydrochloric acid was produced from vitriol (sulfuric acid) and common salt." http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrochloric_acidhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H...
But it is actually a jar of circuit board etchant, which is made from hydrochloric/muriatic acid: http://www.instructables.com/id/PCB-Etching-Solution-Cupric-Chloride/http://www.instructables.com/i...
Yes, you'll probably need PLA for a jar of acetone, although I'm not sure that PLA is completely impervious to acetone over long periods of time. Let us know!

description.text: I'm building a wool picker following the plans in "The Handspinner's Guide to Selling" by Paula Simmons (2nd ed). These plans require cutting and reshaping ~200 20d bright nails. As part of this, they need to be cut to approximately 2" long from their original 4" (the directions are a little muddled as to if they want 1 3/4" or 2 1/4", but I found 2" to be a good compromise). They suggest chucking each nail into a drill press and then using a hacksaw to cut to length before filing a new point, but I found this to be too tedious. Instead, I printed this to provide a guide that I could use my bolt cutters on to get a precise repeat cut. Simply put the nail with the head at the small end, then place the large end flat on the face of the bolt cutters and I got a length that made for easy repeat grinding to the same length.

description.text: A docking station/charging cradle for OnePlus 5. Fits the phone without a case, and a regular Nexus 6P USB-C cable. You'll have to enlarge the design if you have a case on. Furthermore, adjust the size of the USB connector holes if the connector differs in size (for instance, the red USB-C connector that comes with the phone is too short, and will go too deep into the stand with the provided dimensions). The included Fusion 360 file is parametrized, so you should be able to change the various dimensions via the "Modify Parameters" table. The file also has a few steps at the end of the timeline, to generate a slice of the model in order to print out a small prototype to test the size of the USB-C holes.

Printer:

Creality3D CR-10 Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Had a problem with one of the corners at the bottom layer. Resolved it by changing the Shell settings in Cura, forcing it to make the wall 3 layers thick (instead of the default 2). I think it's called perimeters count in S3D.

Infill could probably be less than 20%.

1. Insert the USB-C cable through the opening in the bottom.
  2. Once completely inserted, turn the connector 90 degrees, and push it back into the stand. It should fit snugly, and go exactly as far as needed.
  3. Pass the cable through the groove in the bottom of the stand.

I took the idea from Normand's OnePlus 2 stand. Started from scratch, imitating the original design, and using OnePlus 5 dimensions. If you look at the attached Fusion 360 file, you'll find that the dimensions in the sketch are a little bigger than the published phone dimensions - that's on purpose, to loosen tolerances, and avoid having the phone stuck.

1. One could create a hole below the 3.5mm jack, for connecting headphones/speakers through the cradle.

  2. I haven't implemented it since I don't need it, but one could add higher notches in the front, to allow the use in landscape orientation.

  3. The speaker amplification is unbalanced - it does almost nothing for the bass, while significantly amplifying treble. I'm not a sound engineer, so I don't know how to design the inner tube to improve sound quality. Suggestions are welcome.

description.text:
I was getting quite annoyed with the vertical display on the tronxy x5s, and the fact that you have to be seated in front on the printer to operate it. Therefore I created this angled display. The display is now in the perfect angle when sitting at the table, but still in a good angle when standing.

When mounting the display with this frame, you only need the screws the original display was mounted with. You will probably need to mount the frame on the printer before mounting the display in it, as the screw on the side will otherwise be hard to get to. Then it is a bit fiddly to get the display in, but it can be done without applying force or violence ;)

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I had made some test prints of the display before I got the measurements right. I had therefore set my printer up for quick prototypes, which means 300um layer height, 2 solid top and bottom layers and 2 perimeter walls.

Looking at how much light comes through from the display, I would definitely have printed it finer and with more solid layers if I were to print another.... which I probably will do.

This allows you to adjust the tracking on your OpenRC F1 car,
It also positions both steering arms at the same height (so one is not at an upwards angle like on the original design).

You need an M3 screw which you cut off the head and is screwed into both halves of the track rod (or is it tie-rod?).

To assemble it, screw half the M3 bolt into the inner rod and then cut its head off.
Round off the sharp edges with a file or Dremel and screw the outer rod onto it.

You could put some super-glue or threadlock in the inner rod first, since it is only the outer rod that will need to rotate.

There are 2 versions:

  • For the non-2017 car, you need 2 x 20mm to 25mm M3 screws. (The hole is 12.75mm deep.)
  • For the 2017 car, you need 2 x 20mm to 30mm M3 screws. (The hole is 15mm deep.)

To adjust the steering, disconnect the outer steering rod from the wheel and rotate it half turns until the tracking is correct.

The pictures show it with the front suspension mod, but it works exactly the same with the stock configuration.

If you want to print all 4 pieces at once, you can just download the
Steering_TieRods_All_2017.stl or Steering_TieRods_All.stl file.

Years ago as a child I lost the Power Sword for my original Power Rangers Megazord, so I decided to model a replacement based off some photos. I actually like this version better than the original, since it is much more sturdy!

Since this design ended up looking so great with my Megazord on display, I'm going to attempt to design the Shogun Megazord Power Sword next!

ORACEL RUNE STONES

Traditional oracle rune stones to be used for forecasting the future or just as decoration.

Each rune set contains all 25 stones. Different sets are provided for your personal taste.

Print them, paint them if you want to (using granite effect spray paint, for example).

WHAT ARE RUNES?

The runic alphabet is traditionally known as Futhark, after the first six letters. Casting runes has been used as a form of divination in Europe since the fourth century. The elder Futhark, which you see here, contains 24 runes.

The original meaning of the word rune is "secret, or something hidden". Some indications show that the early runes were not used so much for writing, but rather as magical signs, that means, they were used in magic and for divination (but there is no direct evidence of this). They were probably transformed from the Tarot and the Chinese Book of Changes and were used as the I Ching of the Vikings at that time. With the rune-masters, their wisdom died as well. Nothing was left except the sagas, the scattered fragments of runic history and the rune itself

HOW TO:

  • Put a set (25 stones) into a velvet pouch (available at Amazon or Ebay).
  • Ask a question while shaking the pouch.
  • Then grab one or more runes out of it.

Meanings of the individual runes can be found here: http://bit.ly/2lunL3S

PRINTING:

  • Use 15% infill (or more) to ensure proper print of the engravings.

author: thedany

description.text:
This design was inspired by the Klask game. It is a work in progress, and will be updating as the remainder of the pieces are designed. Photos will be posted as they come.

Designed around these magnets:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M2XB8GZ/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The KLASK game board is shaped like a ball field with two deep holes functioning as goals in each end of the field. In the middle of the field, three white magnetic pieces serve as "obstacles" – do NOT attract them to your own gaming piece! Your gaming piece is a black magnet. You control it by holding a large magnet under the board. This magnet is connected to a small magnet placed on the field. The purpose of the game is to push the small, red ball around on the field with your magnet/gaming piece, shoot the ball past the obstacles and your opponent and into the goal hole (Klask). It’s so much fun when your opponent suddenly is covered in white obstacles or you drop your gaming piece into the goal – something which might happen if you get a little too eager!

Place the game board on a table between the two players. Place the three white magnetic pieces on the white fields on the board. Put two coins in each point slot next to the "0". Each player has a black magnetic gaming piece in two parts. Place the short (thin) part on top of the board and the long (thick) part under the board in such a way, so the two parts “catch” each other. Place the ball in the corner start field. Steer it with the black gaming pieces.

The youngest player starts the game. You score a point if:

The ball ends in your opponent's hole and stays in the hole.
Two or all of the three white magnetic pieces stick to your opponent's gaming piece.
The opponent accidentally pulls their gaming piece into their own goal hole.
If the opponent loses their gaming piece.
Each time you get a point, you must move your coin one point forward in the point slot. The player who first reaches the KLASK field wins.

During the game:

If one of the white magnetic pieces sticks to a gaming piece, the game continues; if two of the white magnetic pieces stick to one gaming piece, the opponent gets one point.
If the ball falls over the edges of the board, you must place the ball in the corner start field in the half from which the ball fell.
If one or more white magnetic pieces fall over the edges of the board, the game continues.
Each time a player scores a point, you must put the white magnetic pieces back on the white fields on the board, and the player who did not score a point places the ball in their corner start field.
