description.text:
The pendulum starter is not an original Ravensburger GraviTrax part.

The idea is that you can load one ball ("marble") on top of the pendulum, and when a ball hits its bottom end, the ball on top will fall on the track. and that 9cm higher than the bottom track.

Its top end is an insert to the original GraviTrax part for the swirl or target hexagons.

You'll need a metal pin (part of a nail e.g.) about 2,5cm long and <2.8mm thick, to be tha axle of the pendulum.

My son and me invented this thing after having a lot of extra bridge piers, and then needed a way to got back up there.

Links to my other GraviTrax compatible parts:

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
My original cardfoam(?) case for my OP-1 was getting a bit tatty, so I set about creating a hard case from 3D printed parts. This is unashamedly modelled on the beautiful - but no longer available, natch - hardwood case from Pendeo.

Designed to fit the 20x20cm print area of yer average printer, the case consists of 6 pieces - so some assembly is required...

In addition, you will need 12 x 5mm dia. 3mm thick neodymium magnets. Of course, these are available online - I use First4Magnets in the UK.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

Bed Temp: 50
Extruder Temp: 200
Print Speed: 50mm/s
Flow: 100%

The lid or top consists of 3 parts - the two large left and right parts plus the 'decorative' sliver in between. These are designed to be glued together with epoxy resin. For a more secure bond, I drilled some small holes on the joints before liberally applying glue, clamping up and allowing the glue to cure fully.

The base consists of the two large parts that again are held together with epoxy resin as above, and the end-cap which is held on with magnets.

The magnets can be glued in with the same epoxy resin. Allow to cure fully before testing, and pay careful attention to the polarity of the magnets - it's crucial that they attract their counterpart in the lid or base!

print_settings.Notes:: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738494

description.text:
If you have a spare 20mm x 2mm circular Neodym magnet, you can make a spare magnetic cannon for your GraviTrax set.

Keep in mind that 3 (THREE) extra original GraviTrax balls are required to fire the cannon!

The "Base-Ramp" file will print a base tile that has a track that is curved upwards to help increase precision of the shots from the cannon - so the ball do not as often drop from the tracks.

Links to my other GraviTrax compatible parts:
Tracks: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738473
Curves, Straights, and Joins: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738494
Pendulum ball starter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738573
Bridge piers: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738439

Notes:

See here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2738494

Remember? You'll need the magnet.

  1. Glue some adhesive tape (Scotch, Tesa, whatever) on both sides of the Neodym magnet disc, to protect it from scattering.
  2. Insert the disc into the slot of the cannon.
  3. If you don't want it to be able to fall out (Kids?) then close the slot with some glue. Be cautious: The magnet must be able to move somewhat in the slot (horizontally) to give the momentum to the nest ball. I used a handheld 3d printer pen to apply some PLA into the slot (The while PLA in the picture)

No

No

Resolution:

.2mm

20%

Notes:

Printed in YOYI PETG using the "Generic PET" settings in Slic3r PE (Prusa Edition).

Mounting Raspberry Pi 3 inside case

The original case bottom has mounting holes for 2mm screws. The Raspberry PI 3 has holes for 2.5mm screws. American (Imperial) #4-40 x 1/4 IN fit the Pi mounting holes very well. I drilled and tapped the existing 2mm holes in the case bottom with an Irwin 4-40 #43 tap and the #4-40 screws are holding nice and firm.

description.text:

comments.author: jcmunozac

comments.text:
It not possible to do it directly in OpenScad (without the Customizer app). I'm using a Matlab script which load the picture, scale it, get the greyscale value and write the function getHMap with the thickness values. Then I copy/past it in the scad file.
If you don't own matlab, it works in GNU Octave (free alternative). This is how I have done the default nenuphar.

author: champystile

title: Weighted base for desk lamp (like IKEA TERTIAL)

description.text:
Quick and easy weighted base for clamp based desk lamp (like IKEA TERTIAL).
……………………
I like my TERTIAL lamp but provided clamp never really worked for me.
I realized I can use cast iron weight plates as weighted base. I tried 5lb weight but it wasn't heavy enough. I settled with 10lb plate I picked up from https://www.dickssportinggoods.com/p/fitness-gear-10-lb-standard-cast-plate-16fgeufg10lbstdcswpl under $9 and it works great even if lamp is fully extended sideways. If you do not plan to swing arm far from base, 5lb will do fine.
Finish with some self sticking felt, cork or rubber pads glued the bottom (I prefer felt so lamp can easily slide on the top of my desk).
……………………
Base center is designed in OpenSCAD for extrusion width 0.5 mm and layer height 0.2 mm. 4 perimeters and 30% infill recommended, no supports required. Print with PETG or ABS, I would not trust PLA for this.
……………………
Source file is included. If you remix, please also share your source file.

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

No

0.2 mm

30%

title: Wanhao/PowerSpec/Monoprice/Cocoon Create Duplicator i3 V2.1 Filament Guide & Camera Mount

description.text:
This is a quick print object to mount avoid unspooling of filament when the Z-axis is high, and has a built-in mount compatible with the modular mount system. I used the camera mount as that's what my webcam supported, but your usage may vary.

See it do what it's meant to do in a 60-second clip:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rIvXoxahTc4

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Doesn't matter*

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed mine at .3mm, but I would recommend going for something a bit lower (<.25mm) as the modular mount part needed much sanding.
This was modeled in the now defunct 123D, but can be opened in Fusion 360, its successor.

This print possesses three parts, the beam (long part), the support (triangle-ish part), and the pin (self explanatory). The beam hooks directly in the center of the machine at the top, and should fit under most 1kg spools. Once in the desired place, the support can be inserted from underneath and the pins aligned. The square pin of the support will stick out the other side, and is where the pin can be inserted to fasten the setup onto the machine. The three prongs on the end are (of course) where the modular mounting system and compatible parts can be mounted.

Raise the x axis to 180mm, then secure ontop of the printer. This will ensure that the lead screw is straight, and will not cause print defects.

One Drive Chain Catcher

A splint I made for a friend who dislocated his finger joint during a basketball game. It is specifically modeled for his finger, but I included Solidworks files so it can be made for any finger.   
The files are a bit messy, if anyone is interested I can post improved versions in the future.  
Printed on a Printrbot Simple with 0.3mm layer height. Total print time is about 35 min.

Marlin 1.1.8 for the TronXY X5S. Fully working!

This has all the improvements I have done to the stock 1.1.6.

If you want to stay on the bleeding edge of Marlin , this is for you.

The way CoreXY is implemented is different on 1.1.8. Your motors may be swapped. If you get inverse motion or swapped X/Y, invert the motor directions!

Manual Mesh Leveling added. 4x4 matrix
Improved homing , and jog speeds from LCD , particularly Z axis. Stock 4mm/s is far to slow
Increased Z max speed. 4mm/s is far to slow to prevent blobbing during Z moves. Max is now 35mm/s
Much improved encoder operation. It now works as expected. Single click for menu items, proper direction, and better multiplier operation when changing values.
EEPROM support enabled.
Filament change options enabled.
Better default Jerk settings.
Proper MAX positions.

Several other small changes.

Minus having to run bed leveling the first time...this is a drop in replacement. Flash and dash....

I suggest executing a "RESTORE FAILSAFE" from the LCD to ensure proper default EEPROM values are loaded immediately after flashing.

comments.author: bugeye59

comments.text:
Well, I made it. I was able to get it updated with my "6 wired" USBASP v2. When I clicked "Upload Using Programmer" it sure took a long while to program. When it finally completed there were some error messages about resetting the ack on the USBASP, but it programmed OK. When programming, Do not power the board and remove the micro sd card and disconnect your raspberry pi if you have octopi.
The USBASP will power the board during programming. Also - When wiring the adapter to 6 pins, do not use PIN 3 of the USBASP for ground. Use PIN 8 instead. I double checked my wiring and discovered my pin 3 was not really ground.

comments.author: Ruckinhell09

comments.text: Mine just arrived and it has no 24v input but I bought a separate 24v 500 watt power supply and an external mosfet both from Amazon.  On the 12v @1.4 ohms (mine measured 1.3) I could not achieve more than 55c without any insulation under it.  With the 24v I was able to achieve 110c within ~5 mins.  edit:  You will have a helluva time unsoldering the 16 awg wiring to the bed unless you use a 250 watt iron at least.  It is the worst solder job I have ever done but it took a heat gun on full force and my soldering iron together to do it and I replaced it with 14 gauge wire silicone jacketed.  Doesn't even get warm but on the power supply to the mosfet I used 14 awg speaker wire I used on my old Prusa and barely warm to the touch.  I can tell it is there in a cold room but not really warmer than my body temp at 110c for 5 mins.
comments.author: Ruckinhell09

comments.text:
Couple of questions...
I have a USB ASP v2.0 ISP programmer. It's 10 pin connector but I have made an adapter to the 6 pin connector on the Melzi board. I did this by routing power/ground/reset/and spi lines to the 6 pin connector.
I am assuming this will work OK? I guess I'll find out pretty quick.
Also - Did I read correct that I am not to power the board when I connect the ISP?

description.text:
This is my first model made in F360 so be understanding :]

I decided to replace stock 40mm extruder fan which is loud as hell! Cause all 40mm low-rpm fans have lower efficiency than Anet fan I chose the 50x15 fan.

In my case it is extremely quiet Sunon HA50151V4-000U-999 (12V, 17dB, 3500RPM).

This duct is compatilble with musta's Anet Tabbed Magnetic Extruder Fan Access remix
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753133

... and is designed for round 4x2 magnets too.

REMARKS:
Due to inconsistent printers tolerances sockets for magnets and pins may need drill a little bit (pins - 3mm, magnets - 4mm).

Duct has been installed in my printer week ago and difference is HUUUUGE! New fan is almost inaudible from more than 1m. Now the blower fan drives me crazy xD

BTW. This mod increase car weight only by 20g.

EDIT 2018/01/10:
I've uploaded the final version of fan duct (Anet a6_fan_50_duct_V4.stl)

Grab stuff with this pneumatic gripper! See the video for assembly instructions.

The sealing technology has been described in the Laser-cutting Pneumatics paper.

Additional materials and tools

Silicone rubber sheet, 1mm thick
4mm (outer diameter) pneumatic tubes, e.g. polyurethane tubes or Lego pneumatic tubes
M3 x 22mm (or longer) bolts and nuts
(Optional) Sealant such as blue silicone
(Optional) Lubricant such as vaseline (petroleum jelly)
(Optional) Something to make 3D printed parts airtight. Impregnating agent "waterdichtmaken.nl" works fine.
Stanley knife with 9mm blade size
Drill with right size for tightly fitting tubes
Clamp
Compressor
Valve

If you do not use sealant and/or when the housing parts are not airtight, significant leakage may occur. The gripper can still be actuated with a high-power compressor, but to make it work with LEGO equipment, adequate airtightness is necessary.

Inside view Troubleshooting

Friction and leakage are the main enemies of any rapid prototyped pneumatic device. It is impossible to fully eliminate both of them, but they can be kept to a minimum by good manufacturing and troubleshooting. Especially when operated with small Lego-sized compressors, super low friction/leakage a must. Laser-cut acrylic top/bottom makes troubleshooting easier. Also see Laser-cutting Pneumatics article.

Friction
  • Check rigid parts (push seals away or remove). If claws do not move by gravity alone: find friction surfaces and grind them, or adjust printer settings (finer detail, lower extrusion etc). If arcs are not circular (check by printing disc): perform XY calibration.
  • Check part height. Housing should be 16mm high, claws 15.7mm. Inconsistent height could be caused by poor bed adhesion resulting in clamping of parts. Make sure the parts do not get loose from the print bed during printing.
  • Check seal dimensions. Ideally, 0.2mm larger than cavity width and height. If too large: reduce seal cutting block dimension (set at 99% etc).
  • Sealant (blue silicone or equivalent) could add excessive friction if not wiped out of the cylinder. Always operate pneumatic gripper a few times at low pressure to clean cylinder walls using the seal. Leftover sealant collected by the seal is normally no problem.
Leakage
  • Through housing: 3D printed parts are usually porous. Solutions: a) print really 100% solid (at the edge of overextrusion), b) apply imprenating agent such as "waterdichtmaken.nl" for PLA or a dilute ABS+acetone mix for ABS parts, c) any other stuff that fills up the pores (paint? nail varnish? ...)
  • Through/along top and bottom cover: if first layer not printed 100% solid, channels will be present along which air can escape. Solution: overextrude first layer, either by extrusion factor or by re-calibrating z offset (lower nozzle). Side-effect: brim. Other solution: fill up channels with stuff.
  • Along walls: too low resolution (e.g. 0.3mm) gives ribbed walls which cannot be sealed off effectively with the seal
  • Along seals: check seal dimensions, should be at least 0.2mm larger than cavity. If too small: scale seal cut block up by 1% or so.
  • Between housing parts: seal off with sealant such as blue silicone; tighten screws.
  • Between housing and air tube: irregular hole or too large hole, or too stiff tube. Solutions: a) use sealant, b) glue tube to housing with e.g. Loctite 770+406.

I designed the first mount that removes the front cage off of the MultiCopter Builders 262/229 quad frame. This design allows for a lower 15mm height, lowering the frame center of gravity.

Testing has shown with a properly tuned quad, the mount performs perfectly. No added vibrations or jello. It actually removed the small shakes I would get with the original FPV Cam mount.

You will also save about 15 grams off the total weight of the quad. More with the Micro Mount.

I also designed a sled mount that will hold the GoPro Session in a sleeve that is held in place by a velcro strap.

This is designed more for the pilot that is into Mid/Long range where protection is required as much as park flyers.

Rafts:

50%

Having recently repairs the looms in my Audi 80 cabrio boot, and with the new loom being larger diameter and the old rubber seals being very perished, I decided to design something that would fill the majority of the gap.

This seal has a reasonably tight fit in all four holes, and allows for a 12mm diameter cable to run through.

The design also allows for retrofitting to existing cables. I intend to use a mastic to bond them in place, and fill the remaining gaps, but they serve a purpose and tidy the area up.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.

This is a keychain I created that uses the miata logo (you can find one alone here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:872369).

I like the thickness it is now, but for someone who likes a slimmer keychain, you can play around with the Z-axis scaling and it comes out great. Dual color was done manually by swapping filaments.

Designed via TinkerCad

title: 2018 New Years Party Picks and Swizzle Sticks

description.text:
Easy print, great conversation starter about 3d printing, fun idea for host/hostess gift for any New Year or 2018 Graduation get together. These are printed in PLA. The only thing you need to be careful of is not to bend the toothpicks by being too quick to peel them off the build platform. The swizzle sticks come in 2 different sizes for tall and short drinks. The toothpicks are also in two sizes. The longer ones you can use for cocktail garnishes (olives, fruit). You can use PETG (which is theoretically food safe although some argue that bacteria could grow in the layers) or PLA.

Even though these are meant for a hard filament I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of several brands of flexible filament, TPU for as little as $1.99 per sample see 3dprintny.com
